name: Jollof Rice (Nigeria)
about: Jollof Rice is a popular West African dish that is known for its vibrant flavors and rich, tomato-infused rice. It is a staple in Nigerian cuisine and is often enjoyed during festive occasions and gatherings. The dish starts with long-grain rice, which is cooked in a flavorful blend of diced tomatoes, tomato paste, onions, garlic, and bell peppers. Spices such as thyme, curry powder, and paprika are added to enhance the taste. Chicken or vegetable broth is used to cook the rice, adding depth and moisture to the dish. The result is a fragrant and delicious rice dish that is enjoyed by people across Nigeria and beyond.
ingredients: - 2 cups of chicken or vegetable broth
instructions: 1. Rinse the rice in cold water and set it aside.
2. Heat oil in a large pot and sauté the onions, garlic, and bell pepper until softened.
3. Add the tomato paste, diced tomatoes, thyme, curry powder, and paprika. Stir and cook for a few minutes.
4. Add the rice and stir to coat it with the tomato mixture.
5. Pour in the broth, season with salt and pepper, and bring it to a boil.
6. Reduce the heat, cover the pot, and simmer for about 20-25 minutes or until the rice is cooked and fluffy.

name: Bunny Chow (South Africa)
about: Bunny Chow is a unique South African street food that originated in the Durban Indian community. It is a dish that combines Indian curry with a hollowed-out loaf of bread, creating a delightful and flavorful meal. The bread loaf acts as a container for the curry, which can be made with chicken, beef, or vegetables. The curry is typically spicy and aromatic, featuring a blend of onions, tomatoes, spices, and herbs. The hollowed-out portion of the bread is filled with the curry, and the combination of the soft bread and the flavorful curry creates a delicious and satisfying eating experience. Bunny Chow is enjoyed by South Africans of all backgrounds and is a popular comfort food in the country.
ingredients: 1 lb (450g) of chicken, beef, or vegetable curry
instructions: Cut a portion of the loaf of bread and hollow out the center, creating a bread bowl.
In a separate pan, prepare your preferred curry using chicken, beef, or vegetables.
Once the curry is cooked, fill the hollowed bread with the curry.
Garnish with chopped onions, tomatoes, green chilies, and coriander leaves.

name: Tagine (Morocco)
description: Tagine is a traditional Moroccan dish that takes its name from the clay pot in which it is cooked. It is a slow-cooked stew that combines tender meat (such as lamb or chicken) with a variety of vegetables and aromatic spices. The dish is known for its unique blend of flavors, which are achieved through the use of spices like cumin, ginger, turmeric, and paprika. The meat and vegetables are cooked together in the tagine pot, allowing the flavors to meld and the meat to become tender and succulent. The addition of preserved lemons, a staple in Moroccan cuisine, adds a tangy and citrusy element to the dish. Tagine is often served with couscous or bread and is enjoyed as a comforting and satisfying meal in Moroccan households.
ingredients: - 1 lb (450g) of lamb or chicken, cubed
instructions: 1. Heat the olive oil in a tagine or a large pot with a tight-fitting lid.
2. Sauté the onion and garlic until softened.
3. Add the meat and brown it on all sides.
4. Add the spices (cumin, ginger, turmeric, and paprika) and stir well.
5. Pour in enough water to cover the meat, then add the carrots, zucchini, and preserved lemon.
6. Cover the tagine or pot and simmer on low heat for about 1.5 to 2 hours, or until the meat is tender.
7. Garnish with fresh cilantro before serving.

name: Doro Wat (Ethiopia)
description: Doro Wat is a flavorful and spicy Ethiopian chicken stew that is often considered the national dish of Ethiopia. It is a rich and hearty dish made with chicken, onions, garlic, ginger, and a unique blend of spices called berbere. Berbere is a spice mixture that typically includes chili peppers, paprika, ginger, coriander, fenugreek, and other spices. The stew is traditionally served with injera, a sourdough flatbread that is used both as a utensil and a staple food in Ethiopian cuisine. Doro Wat is a celebratory dish often enjoyed during holidays and special occasions.
ingredients: - 1.5 lbs (680g) of chicken, cut into pieces
- 2 tablespoons of niter kibbeh (Ethiopian spiced butter)
instructions: 1. Heat the niter kibbeh (Ethiopian spiced butter) in a large pot over medium heat.
2. Add the chopped onions and cook until they are soft and golden brown.
3. Stir in the minced garlic, ginger paste, and berbere spice. Cook for an additional 2 minutes.
4. Add the chicken pieces to the pot and cook until they are browned on all sides.
5. Stir in the tomato paste and chicken broth. Season with salt to taste.
6. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and simmer for about 45 minutes to 1 hour, or until the chicken is tender and the flavors have melded together.
7. If desired, add hard-boiled eggs to the stew during the last 10 minutes of cooking.
8. Serve the Doro Wat with injera or rice.

name: Bobotie (South Africa)
description: Bobotie is a South African dish with Indonesian and Cape Malay influences. It is a spiced meat dish that is baked with an egg-based topping, creating a unique and flavorful combination. Ground beef or lamb is seasoned with curry powder, apricot jam, vinegar, and chutney, giving the dish a sweet and savory taste. Raisins and slivered almonds add texture and additional flavors. The meat mixture is then topped with a mixture of beaten eggs and milk, which forms a golden and custard-like layer when baked. Bobotie is often served with yellow rice and is enjoyed for its comforting and aromatic qualities. It is a dish that showcases the multicultural influences in South African cuisine.
ingredients: - 2 slices of bread, soaked in milk
instructions: 1. Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
2. Heat butter or oil in a pan and sauté the onion and garlic until softened.
3. Add the ground beef or lamb and cook until browned.
4. Stir in the curry powder, apricot jam, vinegar, chutney, raisins, and slivered almonds.
5. Squeeze the excess milk from the soaked bread and add it to the meat mixture. Mix well.
6. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
7. Transfer the mixture to a baking dish and spread it evenly.
8. In a separate bowl, beat the eggs with milk. Pour the egg mixture over the meat.
9. Bake for about 40 minutes, or until the top is golden and set.
10. Serve the Bobotie with yellow rice.

name: Bobotie (South Africa)
about: Bobotie is a traditional South African dish with Cape Malay origins. It is a spiced meat casserole topped with an egg-based custard and baked until golden and set. The dish is typically made with ground beef or lamb, mixed with onions, garlic, curry powder, and other spices, and then topped with a creamy mixture of milk, eggs, and bay leaves. Bobotie is often served with yellow rice and chutney, creating a perfect balance of flavors.
ingredients: - 1 slice of white bread, soaked in milk
instructions: 1. Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C).
2. Heat a small amount of vegetable oil in a pan over medium heat.
3. Add the chopped onions and garlic. Cook until the onions are soft and translucent.
4. Add the ground beef or lamb to the pan and cook until browned, breaking it up into small pieces with a spoon.
5. Stir in the curry powder, turmeric powder, ground cumin, and ground coriander. Cook for an additional 2 minutes.
6. Remove the pan from heat and add the soaked bread (squeeze out excess milk), raisins, apricot jam, and white vinegar. Mix well.
7. Transfer the mixture to a greased baking dish and smooth the top with a spoon.
8. In a separate bowl, whisk together the milk and eggs. Season with salt and pepper.
9. Pour the milk and egg mixture over the meat mixture in the baking dish. Place the bay leaves on top.
10. Bake in the preheated oven for 45-50 minutes, or until the custard is set and golden brown on top.
11. Serve Bobotie hot with yellow rice and chutney.

name: Mafe (Senegal)
about: Mafe, also known as Groundnut Stew, is a popular dish in Senegal and other West African countries. It is a hearty stew made with meat (such as beef, chicken, or lamb), vegetables, and a rich peanut sauce. Mafe is known for its creamy texture and delicious combination of flavors. It is often served with rice or couscous, and the sauce can be thickened with ground peanuts or peanut butter.
ingredients: - 1.5 lbs (680g) of beef, chicken, or lamb, cut into pieces
- 4 cups of chicken or vegetable broth
- 1/2 teaspoon of cayenne pepper (adjust to taste)
instructions: 1. Heat a small amount of vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat.
2. Add the chopped onions and minced garlic. Cook until the onions are soft and translucent.
3. Add the meat to the pot and cook until browned on all sides.
4. Stir in the sliced red bell pepper, carrots, and sweet potato. Cook for a few minutes to soften the vegetables.
5. In a small bowl, mix together the tomato puree, peanut butter, curry powder, cayenne pepper, salt, and pepper.
6. Add the tomato and peanut mixture to the pot, stirring well to coat the meat and vegetables.
7. Pour in the chicken or vegetable broth. Bring the mixture to a boil.
8. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and simmer for 1-2 hours, or until the meat is tender and the flavors have melded together.
9. Adjust the seasoning if needed, adding more salt, pepper, or cayenne pepper to taste.
10. Serve Mafe hot with rice or couscous.

name: Chakalaka (South Africa)
about: Chakalaka is a spicy vegetable relish that is commonly enjoyed in South Africa. It is a vibrant and flavorful dish made with a variety of vegetables, such as onions, bell peppers, carrots, tomatoes, and beans, seasoned with spices and cooked until tender. Chakalaka is often served as a side dish with braai (barbecue) meats or as a condiment to add a spicy kick to other dishes. It is a versatile and colorful addition to any meal.
ingredients: - 1/2 teaspoon of chili powder (adjust to taste)
instructions: 1. Heat the vegetable oil in a large pan over medium heat.
2. Add the chopped onions and cook until they are soft and translucent.
3. Stir in the chopped red and green bell peppers, grated carrots, and chopped tomatoes. Cook for a few minutes until the vegetables have softened.
4. Add the baked beans to the pan, along with their sauce.
5. Sprinkle the curry powder, paprika, ground cumin, and chili powder over the vegetables. Mix well to combine.
6. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
7. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pan, and simmer for 15-20 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld together and the sauce to thicken.
8. Adjust the seasoning if needed, adding more salt, pepper, or chili powder to taste.
9. Serve Chakalaka hot as a side dish or condiment.

name: Braai (South Africa)
about: Braai, also known as a South African barbecue, is a social and culinary tradition that brings people together to enjoy grilled meats, seafood, and vegetables. It is more than just a method of cooking; it is a cultural experience. Braai involves grilling a variety of meats such as boerewors (sausage), lamb chops, steaks, and chicken. The meats are marinated or seasoned with spices, and the grilling is often accompanied by lively music, good company, and flavorful side dishes.
ingredients: - Assortment of meats: boerewors (sausage), lamb chops, steaks, chicken, etc.
- Marinades or spice rubs of your choice
- Side dishes of your choice: salads, bread, grilled vegetables, etc.
instructions: 1. Preheat the grill or barbecue to medium-high heat.
2. Prepare the meats by marinating them or seasoning them with spice rubs. Let them sit for at least 30 minutes to absorb the flavors.
3. Season the meats with salt and pepper to taste.
4. Brush the grill grates with vegetable oil to prevent sticking.
5. Place the meats on the grill and cook to desired doneness, turning occasionally to ensure even cooking.
6. While grilling the meats, you can also grill vegetables, such as corn on the cob, peppers, and mushrooms, for added variety.
7. Once the meats are cooked, remove them from the grill and let them rest for a few minutes before serving.
8. Serve the Braai meats hot with your choice of side dishes, such as salads, bread, or grilled vegetables.
9. Enjoy the delicious flavors of the Braai with family and friends!

name: Dambu Nama (Nigeria)
about: Dambu Nama is a popular Nigerian snack made from dried shredded meat. It is a flavorful and savory treat that is often enjoyed on its own or used as a topping for various dishes. The meat is usually beef or game meat, which is seasoned with spices, smoked, and then dried. The dried meat is shredded and further seasoned with ingredients such as onions, garlic, chili peppers, and spices. Dambu Nama is a delicious and protein-rich snack that is perfect for munching on the go.
ingredients: - 1 lb (450g) of dried shredded beef or game meat
- 2-3 chili peppers, finely chopped (adjust to spice preference)
instructions: 1. Heat vegetable oil in a frying pan or pot over medium heat.
2. Add the chopped onions, minced garlic, and chili peppers. Cook until the onions are soft and translucent.
3. Add the dried shredded beef or game meat to the pan. Stir well to combine with the onions and peppers.
4. Season with ground ginger, ground cloves, ground nutmeg, ground cinnamon, and salt. Mix thoroughly to coat the meat with the spices.
5. Reduce the heat to low and continue to cook for about 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent burning.
6. Remove the pan from heat and let the Dambu Nama cool.
7. Once cooled, store the Dambu Nama in an airtight container.
8. Enjoy the Dambu Nama as a snack or use it as a topping for salads, soups, or stews.

name: Piri Piri Chicken (Mozambique)
about: Piri Piri Chicken is a spicy grilled chicken dish that originated in Mozambique and has gained popularity worldwide. The name 'Piri Piri' refers to the African bird's-eye chili pepper, which is a key ingredient in the marinade and sauce for this dish. The chicken is marinated in a flavorful mixture of spices, herbs, lemon juice, and Piri Piri sauce, then grilled to perfection. The result is juicy, tender chicken with a fiery kick of heat. Piri Piri Chicken is often served with rice, fries, or a fresh salad.
ingredients: - 4-6 bird's-eye chili peppers, finely chopped (adjust to spice preference)
instructions: 1. In a bowl, combine the chopped bird's-eye chili peppers, minced garlic, lemon juice, Piri Piri sauce, olive oil, paprika, dried oregano, salt, and pepper.
2. Place the chicken pieces in a large resealable bag or container.
3. Pour the marinade over the chicken, ensuring that each piece is well coated. Seal the bag or cover the container, and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, or overnight for best results.
4. Preheat the grill to medium-high heat.
5. Remove the chicken from the marinade and shake off any excess.
6. Grill the chicken on the preheated grill, turning occasionally, until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C) and the chicken is cooked through.
7. Baste the chicken with any remaining marinade during grilling for added flavor.
8. Remove the chicken from the grill and let it rest for a few minutes before serving.
9. Serve the Piri Piri Chicken hot with rice, fries, or a fresh salad.

name: Ful Medames (Egypt)
about: Ful Medames is a traditional Egyptian dish made from cooked fava beans. It is a popular and nutritious breakfast or brunch dish that is packed with protein, fiber, and flavor. The fava beans are simmered with garlic, lemon juice, olive oil, and a blend of spices until they are soft and creamy. Ful Medames is typically served with pita bread and garnished with ingredients like chopped tomatoes, onions, parsley, and a drizzle of olive oil. It is a hearty and satisfying dish that is enjoyed across Egypt and the Middle East.
ingredients: - Chopped tomatoes, onions, and parsley for garnish
instructions: 1. Rinse the dried fava beans under cold water. Soak them in water overnight or for at least 8 hours.
2. Drain the soaked fava beans and transfer them to a large pot. Add enough water to cover the beans by a few inches.
3. Bring the water to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for about 1-2 hours, or until the beans are soft and easily mashed with a fork.
4. Drain the cooked fava beans, reserving some of the cooking liquid.
5. In a bowl, mash the fava beans with a fork or a potato masher until they reach a chunky consistency.
6. Stir in the minced garlic, lemon juice, olive oil, ground cumin, ground coriander, salt, and pepper. Adjust the seasonings to taste.
7. If the mixture is too thick, gradually add some of the reserved cooking liquid until you reach the desired consistency.
8. Serve Ful Medames hot, topped with chopped tomatoes, onions, parsley, and a drizzle of olive oil. Serve with pita bread for scooping.
9. Enjoy the flavorful and nutritious Ful Medames!

name: Chapati (East Africa)
about: Chapati is a popular unleavened flatbread that is widely consumed in East Africa. It is a versatile bread that can be enjoyed with a variety of dishes or used as a wrap for fillings. Chapati is made from a simple dough consisting of flour, water, salt, and oil. The dough is kneaded, rolled out into thin circles, and cooked on a griddle or skillet until it puffs up and develops golden brown spots. Chapati is soft, slightly chewy, and makes a delicious accompaniment to curries, stews, or grilled meats.
instructions: 1. In a large bowl, combine the all-purpose flour and salt.
2. Gradually add water to the flour mixture, mixing with your hands or a spoon, until a soft and pliable dough forms. Adjust the amount of water as needed.
3. Knead the dough on a lightly floured surface for about 5 minutes, or until it becomes smooth and elastic.
4. Divide the dough into small golf ball-sized portions.
5. Roll each portion into a thin circle, dusting with flour as needed to prevent sticking.
6. Brush the surface of each rolled-out chapati with vegetable oil.
7. Heat a griddle or skillet over medium-high heat.
8. Place a chapati on the hot griddle and cook for about 1-2 minutes, or until it starts to puff up and develops golden brown spots.
9. Flip the chapati and cook the other side for an additional 1-2 minutes.
10. Remove the cooked chapati from the griddle and keep it warm in a clean kitchen towel.
11. Repeat the process with the remaining portions of dough, adding more oil to the griddle as needed.
12. Serve the Chapati warm as a side bread with curries, stews, or grilled meats.
13. Enjoy the soft and flavorful Chapati!

name: Fesenjan (Iran)
about: Fesenjan is a rich and flavorful Persian stew made with ground walnuts, pomegranate molasses, and meat (usually chicken or duck). It is a beloved dish in Iranian cuisine and is often served on special occasions and holidays. The combination of nutty walnuts and tangy pomegranate molasses creates a unique and delicious flavor profile. Fesenjan is traditionally served with rice and garnished with pomegranate seeds for a touch of freshness and color.
ingredients: - 1 lb (450g) of chicken or duck, cut into pieces
instructions: 1. Heat vegetable oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat.
2. Add the chopped onion to the pot and cook until it is soft and golden brown.
3. Add the chicken or duck pieces to the pot and cook until they are browned on all sides.
4. Stir in the ground walnuts, pomegranate molasses, ground cinnamon, ground turmeric, ground nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Mix well to combine.
5. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and simmer for about 1-2 hours, or until the meat is tender and the flavors have melded together.
6. Stir the Fesenjan occasionally to prevent sticking or burning.
7. Adjust the seasoning if needed.
8. Serve Fesenjan hot with cooked rice.
9. Garnish with pomegranate seeds for a pop of color and freshness.
10. Enjoy the rich and tangy flavors of Fesenjan!

name: Dibi (Senegal)
about: Dibi is a popular Senegalese dish made with grilled lamb or goat meat. The meat is marinated in a mixture of lemon juice, mustard, garlic, and spices, then grilled over an open flame. Dibi is often served with onions and a spicy dipping sauce called 'sauce d'arachide' (which is made with peanut butter, tomato paste, and chili peppers.)
ingredients: - 2 lbs (900g) of lamb or goat meat, cut into chunks
instructions: 1. In a large bowl, combine the lemon juice, Dijon mustard, minced garlic, ground black pepper, dried thyme, paprika, and salt. Mix well to create a marinade.
2. Add the lamb or goat meat to the marinade and toss to coat the meat evenly. Ensure that all the meat is covered in the marinade.
3. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight, to allow the flavors to meld.
4. Preheat the grill to medium-high heat.
5. Remove the meat from the marinade and shake off any excess.
6. Thread the meat onto skewers, leaving a small gap between each piece.
7. Grill the skewers for about 10-15 minutes, turning occasionally, or until the meat is browned and cooked to your desired doneness.
8. Serve the Dibi skewers with onion slices and a side of sauce d'arachide for dipping.
9. Enjoy the smoky and flavorful Senegalese Dibi!

name: Kitfo (Ethiopia)
about: Kitfo is a traditional Ethiopian dish made with minced raw beef, seasoned with spices, and served with injera (a sourdough flatbread) and various accompaniments. The beef is typically mixed with clarified butter and spiced with mitmita (a chili powder blend) and niter kibbeh (spiced butter). Kitfo can be enjoyed as a main dish or as part of a larger Ethiopian meal.
ingredients: - Accompaniments (such as ayib, collard greens, and lentil dishes)
instructions: 1. Heat the clarified butter in a skillet over low heat until it melts.
2. In a bowl, combine the minced beef, melted clarified butter, mitmita, and salt. Mix well to evenly distribute the spices.
3. Divide the seasoned beef into individual portions and shape them into small balls or patties.
4. Serve the Kitfo with injera and a selection of accompaniments.
5. To enjoy, tear off a piece of injera, place a portion of Kitfo on top, and use the injera to scoop up the meat and accompaniments.
6. Enjoy the unique flavors and textures of Ethiopian Kitfo!

name: Kachumbari (Kenya)
about: Kachumbari is a fresh and vibrant Kenyan salad made with diced tomatoes, onions, and cucumbers, dressed with lemon juice and chopped cilantro. It is a popular accompaniment to grilled meats, stews, and rice dishes in Kenya. Kachumbari is a refreshing salad that adds a burst of flavor and crunch to any meal.
instructions: 1. In a large bowl, combine the diced tomatoes, chopped onion, and diced cucumber.
2. Squeeze the lemon juice over the vegetables and sprinkle with salt and pepper.
3. Add the chopped cilantro to the bowl and toss all the ingredients together until well combined.
4. Let the Kachumbari salad sit for about 15-20 minutes to allow the flavors to meld together.
5. Serve the Kachumbari as a refreshing side salad or accompaniment to grilled meats, stews, or rice dishes.
6. Enjoy the vibrant and tangy Kenyan Kachumbari!

name: Nyama Choma (Kenya)
about: Nyama Choma is a popular Kenyan dish that consists of grilled or roasted meat, typically beef or goat. The meat is marinated with spices and grilled over an open flame or roasted in an oven until it is tender and charred on the outside. Nyama Choma is often enjoyed as a social meal, with friends and family gathering to savor the flavors of the grilled meat.
ingredients: - 2 lbs (900g) of beef or goat meat, cut into chunks
instructions: 1. In a bowl, combine the vegetable oil, chopped onion, minced garlic, ginger paste, paprika, ground cumin, ground coriander, black pepper, lemon juice, and salt. Mix well to form a marinade.
2. Place the chunks of meat in the marinade, ensuring that they are well coated. Cover the bowl and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or overnight for maximum flavor.
3. Preheat the grill to medium-high heat or preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C).
4. If using a grill, thread the marinated meat onto skewers, leaving a small gap between each piece. If using the oven, place the marinated meat on a roasting rack set over a baking sheet.
5. Grill the skewers or roast the meat in the oven for about 15-20 minutes, turning occasionally, or until the meat is browned and cooked to your desired doneness.
6. Remove the meat from the grill or oven and let it rest for a few minutes before serving.
7. Serve the Nyama Choma hot with your choice of accompaniments, such as Ugali (a cornmeal porridge), Sukuma Wiki (braised collard greens), or Kachumbari (a Kenyan tomato and onion salad).
8. Enjoy the succulent and flavorful Kenyan Nyama Choma!

name: Attiéké (Ivory Coast)
about: Attiéké is a traditional Ivorian dish made from fermented cassava. It is similar to couscous in texture and is commonly served as a side dish or accompaniment to various stews, grilled fish, or roasted meat. Attiéké has a slightly tangy flavor and a light and fluffy texture, making it a versatile and delicious addition to any meal.
instructions: 1. Place the attiéké in a large bowl.
2. Pour the boiling water over the attiéké and let it sit for about 5 minutes, allowing the grains to absorb the water.
3. Fluff the attiéké with a fork to separate the grains and break up any clumps.
4. In a skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat.
5. Add the fluffed attiéké to the skillet and stir-fry it for about 5 minutes, or until it is heated through and lightly toasted.
6. Season the attiéké with salt to taste and mix well.
7. Remove the attiéké from the heat and let it cool slightly before serving.
8. Serve the Attiéké as a side dish or accompaniment to stews, grilled fish, or roasted meat.
9. Enjoy the tangy and fluffy Ivorian Attiéké!

name: Maafe (Senegal)
about: Maafe, also known as Groundnut Stew, is a popular Senegalese dish made with a rich and hearty sauce made from ground peanuts, tomatoes, and a variety of vegetables and meats. It is often prepared with beef, lamb, or chicken, and it is seasoned with aromatic spices such as garlic, ginger, and chili peppers. Maafe is typically served with rice or couscous and is loved for its comforting and flavorsome nature.
ingredients: - 1 lb (450g) of beef, lamb, or chicken, cut into chunks
- 1 can (14 oz or 400g) of diced tomatoes
- 4 cups of vegetable or chicken broth
- 1 scotch bonnet pepper or chili pepper, chopped (adjust quantity for desired spice level)
instructions: 1. In a large pot or Dutch oven, heat a tablespoon of oil over medium heat.
2. Add the chopped onion, minced garlic, and grated ginger to the pot. Sauté until the onions are translucent and the mixture is fragrant.
3. Add the meat chunks to the pot and brown them on all sides.
4. Stir in the tomato paste, diced tomatoes, and peanut butter. Mix well to combine all the ingredients.
5. Pour in the vegetable or chicken broth, ensuring that the meat is covered with liquid.

6. Add the sliced carrots, cubed potatoes, chopped bell pepper, scotch bonnet pepper or chili pepper, paprika, ground cumin, ground coriander, salt, and pepper to the pot. Stir well to distribute the spices and vegetables.
7. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low. Cover the pot and simmer for about 1.5 to 2 hours, or until the meat is tender and the flavors have melded together.
8. Adjust the seasoning with salt and pepper to taste.
9. Remove the pot from the heat and let the Maafe rest for a few minutes.
10. Serve the Maafe hot with rice or couscous, garnished with fresh cilantro.
11. Enjoy the rich and comforting Senegalese Maafe!
